results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to evaluate the frequency and sequential transition between SRL processes. Methods like logistic regression and ONA are mentioned.
Sections 3.1-3.4 provide a detailed step-by-step description of the study design, including participant recruitment, data collection, data processing, and analysis techniques.
The document states: "A complete table of this framework can be found in this online repository 1 https://osf.io/4jrva?view_only=074618c2bcd742bcb3dc9a1d9b4d3317"
While a repository is linked, it's unclear if the raw or processed datasets are available there. The text only mentions a framework.
Section 3.3.1 and 3.3.2 describe the trace parser and data processing steps, effectively acting as a data dictionary. Table 1 provides details on SRL processes.
Section 3.1 and 3.2 detail the data collection methods, including the essay writing task, the Flora learning platform, and participant demographics.
The document mentions the use of R (Version 4.3.2) and the ONA package (version 0.1.1.1684949787) with a link to the package: https://cran.qe-libs.org/ona/index.html
The document does not explicitly state whether the full analysis code is shared in a public repository like GitHub or GitLab.
Section 3.3.1 and 3.3.2 describe the trace parser and data processing steps, which can be considered code for data preparation.
Logistic regression and ordered network analysis (ONA) are clearly described, including addressing multicollinearity (VIFs) and sparsity.
Effect sizes (Cohen’s d), p-values, and statistical test results (e.g., chi-square, t-tests) are reported throughout the results sections.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
No qualitative data coding or analysis is described.
Results are presented in a structured manner, organized by learning block and research question, with references to figures and statistical outputs.
Section 4.6 discusses limitations related to the learning blocks and potential individual differences, as well as the possibility of outliers.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
